Navigator.summary: The Navigator interface represents the state and the identity of the user agent. It allows scripts to query it and to register themselves to carry on some activities.

remarks.para: A Navigator object can be retrieved using the read-only property.

NavigatorActiveVRDisplays.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The activeVRDisplays read-only property of the
interface returns an array containing every
object that is currently presenting
( is true).

blockquote.para: This property was part of the old WebVR API. It has been superseded by the WebXR Device API.

remarks.para: -WebVR API

NavigatorAppCodeName.summary:
The value of the Navigator.appCodeName property is
always "Mozilla", in any browser. This property is kept only for
compatibility purposes.

blockquote.para:
Do not rely on this property to return a real
product name. All browsers return "Mozilla" as the value of this property.

NavigatorAppName.summary:
The value of the Navigator.appName property is always
"Netscape", in any browser. This property is kept only for compatibility
purposes.

blockquote.para: Do not rely on this property to return a real browser name. All browsers return "Netscape" as the value of this property.

NavigatorAppVersion.summary:
Returns either "4.0" or a string representing version information about
the browser.

blockquote.para: Do not rely on this property to return the correct browser version.

NavigatorAppVersion.value:
Either "4.0" or a string representing version information about the
browser.

NavigatorBluetooth.summary: NOTE Experimental The bluetooth read-only property of the interface returns a object for the current document, providing access to Web Bluetooth API functionality.

remarks.para: -Web Bluetooth API

NavigatorBuildID.summary: CAUTION Non-standard Returns the build identifier of the browser. In modern browsers this property now returns a fixed timestamp as a privacy measure, e.g., 20181001000000 in Firefox 64 onwards.
NavigatorBuildID.value: A string representing the build identifier of the application. The build ID is in the form YYYYMMDDHHMMSS.

NavigatorCanShare.summary: The canShare() method of the interface returns true if the equivalent call to would succeed.

remarks.para: The method returns false if the data cannot be validated. Reasons the data might be invalid include:

The Web Share API is gated by the web-share permission policy.
The canShare() method will return false if the permission is supported but has not been granted.

NavigatorCanShare.returns: Returns true if the specified data can be shared with , otherwise false.

NavigatorClearAppBadge.summary: The clearAppBadge() method of the interface clears a badge on the current app's icon by setting it to nothing. The value nothing indicates that no badge is currently set, and the status of the badge is cleared.

remarks.para: -Badging for app icons

NavigatorClipboard.summary: The clipboard read-only property of the interface returns a object used to read and write the clipboard's contents.

remarks.para: This is the entry point to the Clipboard API, which can be used to implement cut, copy, and paste features within a web application.

NavigatorClipboard.value: The object used to access the system clipboard.

NavigatorConnection.summary: The connection read-only property of the interface returns a object containing information about the system's connection, such as the current bandwidth of the user's device or whether the connection is metered.

remarks.para: This could be used to select high definition content or low definition content based on the user's connection.
-Online and offline events

NavigatorContacts.summary:
NOTE Experimental The contacts read-only property of the
interface returns a interface
which allows users to select entries from their contact list and share limited details
of the selected entries with a website or application.

remarks.para:
-A Contact Picker for the Web
-Contact Picker API live demo

NavigatorContacts.value: A object. Two successive calls return the same object.

NavigatorCookieEnabled.summary: navigator.cookieEnabled returns a Boolean value that indicates whether cookies are enabled or not.

remarks.para: The property is read-only.

NavigatorCookieEnabled.value:
A boolean.
NOTEWeb browsers may prevent writing certain cookies in certain scenarios. For example, Chrome-based browsers, as well as some experimental version of Firefox, does not allow creating cookies with SameSite=None attribute, unless they are created over HTTPS and with Secure attribute.

NavigatorCredentials.summary: The credentials read-only property of the interface returns the object associated with the current document, which exposes methods to request credentials. The interface also notifies the user agent when an interesting event occurs, such as a successful sign-in or sign-out. This interface can be used for feature detection.

NavigatorDeprecatedReplaceInURN.summary: NOTE Experimental The deprecatedReplaceInURN() method of the interface substitutes specified strings inside the mapped URL corresponding to a given opaque URN or FencedFrameConfig's internal url property.

remarks.para: A FencedFrameConfig or opaque URN is returned from a source such as the Protected Audience API runAdAuction() method, and then set as the value of . The content URL associated with the FencedFrameConfig or opaque URN is mapped to it internally by the browser, and can't be accessed via JavaScript.

However, you may wish to substitute parts of that internal URL. This is a common approach for passing runtime data into ad creatives to use in rendering. deprecatedReplaceInURN() has been made available as a temporary measure to enable that substitution for fenced frame URLs, helping ad tech providers to migrate existing implementations across to privacy sandbox APIs.
-Fenced Frame API

NavigatorDeviceMemory.summary:
The deviceMemory read-only
property of the interface returns the approximate amount of
device memory in gigabytes.

remarks.para:
The reported value is imprecise to curtail fingerprinting. It's approximated by
rounding down to the nearest power of 2, then dividing that number by 1024. It is then
clamped within lower and upper bounds to protect the privacy of owners of very low-memory or
high-memory devices.
-Device-Memory HTTP header

NavigatorDeviceMemory.value: A floating point number; one of 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8.

NavigatorDevicePosture.summary: NOTE Experimental The Navigator.devicePosture read-only property returns the browser's object, which allows developers to query the device's current posture (that is, whether the viewport is in a flat or folded state) and run code in response to posture changes.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Device Posture API
-CSS @media/device-posture _media feature

NavigatorDoNotTrack.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The Navigator.doNotTrack property returns the user's Do Not Track setting, which indicates whether the user is requesting websites and advertisers to not track them.

remarks.para: The value of the property reflects that of the DNT HTTP header, i.e., values of "1", "0", or null.

The whole DNT (Do Not Track) specification has been discontinued. The mechanism design was flawed, because it was a cooperative feature between users, websites, and browsers. The idea is that the user tells the website to not track them, and the website would comply. However, there is no strict enforcement of this policy, so advertisement websites ignored the DNT header and tracked users anyway. The feature is therefore useless. Moreover, it is harmful as it leaves more user fingerprint in the header, which can be used to track users even more.
Browsers are exploring other more enforceable privacy features, such as global privacy control, restriction to third-party cookies, and more.
-DNT HTTP header

NavigatorGeolocation.summary:
The Navigator.geolocation read-only property returns a
object that gives Web content access to the location of the
device. This allows a website or app to offer customized results based on the user's
location.

blockquote.para:
For security reasons, when a web page tries to access location
information, the user is notified and asked to grant permission. Be aware that each
browser has its own policies and methods for requesting this permission.

remarks.para: -Using the Geolocation API

NavigatorGetAutoplayPolicy.summary: NOTE Experimental The getAutoplayPolicy() method of the Autoplay Policy Detection API provides information about whether autoplay of media elements and audio contexts is allowed, disallowed, or only allowed if the audio is muted.

remarks.para:
Applications can use this information to provide an appropriate user experience.
For example, if the user agent policy only allows autoplay of inaudible content, the application might mute videos so that they can still autoplay.
The method can be used to get either the broad autoplay policy for all items of a particular type in the document, or for specific media elements or audio contexts.
-Autoplay guide for media and Web Audio APIs

NavigatorGetAutoplayPolicy.returns:
A string indicating the autoplay policy for the specified media feature type, element, or context.
This will be a string containing one of the following values:Note that the autoplay policy returned for a type parameter is the broad policy for items of the indicated type.
On page load, all items of a type will have the same policy as the type.
Once the user has interacted with the page/site, on some browsers individual items may have a different policy to the corresponding type.

NavigatorGetBattery.summary:
The getBattery() method provides information about the system's battery.
It returns a battery promise, which resolves with a object providing some properties to get the battery status also some events you can handle to monitor the battery status.
This implements the {{domxref("Battery Status API", "", "", "nocode")}}; see that documentation for additional details, a guide to using the API, and sample code.

remarks.para: Since Chrome 103, the Navigator.getBattery() method of {{domxref("Battery Status API", "", "", "nocode")}} only expose to secure context.

blockquote.para: Access to this feature may be controlled by the Permissions-Policy directive Permissions-Policy/battery.

remarks.para:
-{{domxref("Battery Status API", "", "", "nocode")}}
-Permissions-Policy Permissions-Policy/battery directive

NavigatorGetBattery.returns: A {{JSxRef("Promise")}} that fulfills with a object which you can use to get information about the battery's state.

NavigatorGetGamepads.summary:
The Navigator.getGamepads() method returns an array of
objects, one for each gamepad connected to the device.

remarks.para:
Elements in the array may be null if a gamepad disconnects during a
session, so that the remaining gamepads retain the same index.

-Using the Gamepad API
-Gamepad API

NavigatorGetInstalledRelatedApps.summary: NOTE Experimental The getInstalledRelatedApps() method returns a promise that resolves with an array of objects representing any related platform-specific apps or Progressive Web Apps that the user has installed. This could be used for content personalization such as removing "install our app" banners from the web app if the platform-specific app and/or PWA is already installed.

blockquote.para: This method must be invoked in a top-level secure context, that is, not embedded in an iframe.

remarks.para: -Is your app installed? getInstalledRelatedApps() will tell you!

NavigatorGetInstalledRelatedApps.returns: A that fulfills with an array of objects representing any installed related apps. Each object can contain the following properties:The related app information must have been previously specified in the related_applications member of the invoking web app's manifest file.

NavigatorGetUserMedia.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The deprecated Navigator.getUserMedia() method prompts the user for permission to use up to one video input device (such as a camera or shared screen) and up to one audio input device (such as a microphone) as the source for a .

remarks.para:
If permission is granted, a MediaStream whose video and/or audio tracks come from those devices is delivered to the specified success callback.
If permission is denied, no compatible input devices exist, or any other error condition occurs, the error callback is executed with an object describing what went wrong.
If the user instead doesn't make a choice at all, neither callback is executed.

blockquote.para:
This is a legacy method.
Please use the newer instead.
While technically not deprecated, this old callback version is marked as such, since the specification strongly encourages using the newer promise returning version.

remarks.para:
- that replaces this deprecated method.
-WebRTC - the introductory page to the API
-Media Capture and Streams API - the API for the
media stream objects
-Taking webcam photos - a
tutorial on using getUserMedia() for taking photos rather than video.

NavigatorGetVRDisplays.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The getVRDisplays() method of the interface returns a promise that resolves to an array of objects representing any available VR displays connected to the computer.

remarks.para: -WebVR API homepage

NavigatorGetVRDisplays.returns: A promise that resolves to an array of objects.

NavigatorGlobalPrivacyControl.summary:
NOTE Experimental The Navigator.globalPrivacyControl read-only property returns the user's Global Privacy Control setting for the current website.
This setting indicates whether the user consents to the website or service selling or sharing their personal information with third parties.

remarks.para: The value of the property reflects that of the Sec-GPC HTTP header.

-Sec-GPC header
-globalprivacycontrol.org
-Do Not Track on Wikipedia

NavigatorGlobalPrivacyControl.value:
true if the user explicitly does not provide consent to sell or share their data.
false if the user either grants consent, or has not indicated a preference.

NavigatorGpu.summary: The Navigator.gpu read-only property returns the object for the current browsing context, which is the entry point for the {{domxref("WebGPU_API", "WebGPU API", "", "nocode")}}.

remarks.para: -{{domxref("WebGPU_API", "WebGPU API", "", "nocode")}}

NavigatorHardwareConcurrency.summary:
The navigator.hardwareConcurrency read-only property
returns the number of logical processors available to run threads on the user's
computer.
NavigatorHardwareConcurrency.value:
A number between 1 and the number of logical processors potentially available to the user agent.Modern computers have multiple physical processor cores in their CPU (two or four cores
is typical), but each physical core is also usually able to run more than one thread at
a time using advanced scheduling techniques. So a four-core CPU may offer eight
logical processor cores, for example. The number of logical processor
cores can be used to measure the number of threads which can effectively be run at once
without them having to context switch.The browser may, however, choose to report a lower number of logical cores in order to
represent more accurately the number of s that can run at once, so
don't treat this as an absolute measurement of the number of cores in the user's system.

NavigatorHid.summary:
NOTE Experimental The Navigator.hid
read-only property returns an object providing methods for accessing HID device connections and events that fire when the user agent connects to or disconnects from a device.

remarks.para: Where a defined Permissions Policy blocks WebHID usage, the Navigator.hid property will not be available.
-WebHID API

NavigatorInk.summary: NOTE Experimental The ink read-only property of the interface returns an object for the current document, providing access to Ink API functionality.

NavigatorKeyboard.summary:
NOTE Experimental The keyboard read-only property
of the interface returns a object
which provides access to functions that retrieve keyboard layout maps and toggle
capturing of key presses from the physical keyboard.

NavigatorLanguage.summary: The language read-only property of the interface returns a string representing the preferred language of the user, usually the language of the browser UI.
NavigatorLanguage.value: A string representing the language version as defined in {{RFC(5646, "Tags for Identifying Languages (also known as BCP 47)")}}. Examples of valid language codes include "en", "en-US", "fr", "fr-FR", "es-ES", etc.Note that in Safari on iOS prior to 10.2, the country code returned is lowercase: "en-us", "fr-fr" etc.

NavigatorLanguages.summary:
The languages read-only property of the interface
returns an array of strings representing the user's preferred
languages. The language is described using language tags according to
{{RFC(5646, "Tags for Identifying Languages (also known as BCP 47)")}}. In the returned
array they are ordered by preference with the most preferred language first.

remarks.para:
The value of is the
first element of the returned array.

When its value changes, as the user's preferred languages are changed a
event is fired on the object.

The Accept-Language HTTP header in every HTTP request from the user's browser generally lists the same locales as the navigator.languages property, with decreasing q values (quality values). Some browsers (Chrome and Safari) add language-only fallback tags in Accept-Languageâ€”for example, en-US,en;q=0.9,zh-CN;q=0.8,zh;q=0.7 when navigator.languages is ["en-US", "zh-CN"]. For privacy purposes (reducing fingerprinting), both Accept-Language and navigator.languages may not include the full list of user preferences, such as in Safari (always) and Chrome's incognito mode, where only one language is listed.

-
-
- event
-

NavigatorLocks.summary:
The locks read-only property of
the interface returns a object
which provides methods for requesting a new object and querying
for an existing Lock object.

NavigatorLogin.summary: The login read-only property of the interface provides access to the browser's object, which a federated identity provider (IdP) can use to set its login status when a user signs into or out of the IdP.

remarks.para: See Update login status using the Login Status API for more details of how this is used.
-Federated Credential Management (FedCM) API

NavigatorMaxTouchPoints.summary:
The maxTouchPoints read-only property of the
interface returns the maximum number of simultaneous touch
contact points that are supported by the current device.

NavigatorMediaCapabilities.summary: The mediaCapabilities read-only property of the interface references a object that can expose information about the decoding and encoding capabilities for a given media format and output capabilities.

remarks.para:
-Media Capabilities API
-

NavigatorMediaDevices.summary: The mediaDevices read-only property of the interface returns a object, which provides access to connected media input devices like cameras and microphones, as well as screen sharing.

remarks.para:
-Media Capture and Streams API: The entry point to the documentation about the entire Media Capture and Streams API.
-WebRTC API: Documentation about the WebRTC API, which is closely related.

NavigatorMediaDevices.value: The singleton object. Usually, you just use this object's members directly, such as by calling .

NavigatorMediaSession.summary:
The mediaSession read-only property of the
interface returns a
object that can be used to share with the browser metadata and other information about
the current playback state of media being handled by a document.

remarks.para:
This
information may, in turn, be shared with the device and/or operating system in order to
a device's standard media control user experience to describe and control the playback
of the media.

In addition, the MediaSession interface provides the
method, which lets
you receive events when the user engages device controls such as either onscreen or
physical play, pause, seek, and other similar controls. An internet radio app, for
example, can use setActionHandler() to let the media controls on a keyboard
or elsewhere on the user's device be used to control the app's media playback.

NavigatorMediaSession.value:
A object the current document can use to share information
about media it's playing and its current playback status. This information can include
typical metadata such as the title, artist, and album name of the song being played as
well as potentially one or more images containing things like album art, artist photos,
and so forth.

NavigatorMimeTypes.summary:
Returns a object, which contains a list of objects representing the MIME types recognized and supported by the browser.
The array can be queried for information about the enabled plugin that is used to handle a file of the specified type.
Named properties of the returned object are not enumerable (except in very old browser versions).

remarks.para:
Recent versions of the specification hard-code the returned set of MIME types.
If PDF files can be displayed inline then application/pdf and text/pdf are listed.
Otherwise an empty list is returned.

blockquote.para: Use to determine if inline viewing of PDF files is supported. Do not infer it from this property.

remarks.para: Legacy browser versions do not hard-code the list returned by the property, and might return other MIME types.

NavigatorMimeTypes.value:
A MimeTypeArray object which has a length property as well as item(index) and namedItem(name) methods.If PDF inline viewing is supported this has entries for MIME types application/pdf and text/pdf.
Otherwise an empty MimeTypeArray is returned.
The description and file suffixes supported by enabled plugins are hard coded to 'pdf' and 'Portable Document Format', respectively.

NavigatorOnLine.summary: The onLine property of the interface returns whether the device is connected to the network, with true meaning online and false meaning offline. The property's value changes after the browser checks its network connection, usually when the user follows links or when a script requests a remote page. For example, the property should return false when users click links soon after they lose internet connection. When its value changes, an online or offline event is fired on the window.

remarks.para: Browsers and operating systems leverage different heuristics to determine whether the device is online. In general, connection to LAN is considered online, even though the LAN may not have Internet access. For example, the computer may be running a virtualization software that has virtual ethernet adapters that are always "connected". On Windows, the online status is determined by whether it can reach a Microsoft home server, which may be blocked by firewalls or VPNs, even if the computer has Internet access. Therefore, this property is inherently unreliable, and you should not disable features based on the online status, only provide hints when the user may seem offline.

NavigatorOscpu.summary: The Navigator.oscpu property returns a string that identifies the current operating system.
NavigatorOscpu.value:
A string providing a string which identifies the operating system on which the browser is running.
Operating systemoscpuInfo string format
OS/2OS/2 Warp x (either 3, 4 or 4.5)
Windows CEWindowsCE x.y
Windows 64-bit (64-bit build)Windows NT x.y; Win64; x64
Windows 64-bit (32-bit build)Windows NT x.y; WOW64
Windows 32-bitWindows NT x.y
Mac OS X (PPC build)PowerPC Mac OS X version x.y
Mac OS X (i386/x64 build)Intel Mac OS X or macOS version x.y
Linux 64-bit (32-bit build)Output of uname -s followed by i686 on x86_64
LinuxOutput of uname -smIn this table x.y refers to the version of the operating system

NavigatorPdfViewerEnabled.summary: The pdfViewerEnabled read-only property of the interface indicates whether the browser supports inline display of PDF files when navigating to them.

remarks.para: If inline viewing is not supported the PDF is downloaded and may then be handled by some external application.

blockquote.para: This method replaces a number of legacy methods of inferring support for inline viewing of PDF files.

NavigatorPdfViewerEnabled.value: true if the browser can display PDF files inline when navigating to the file (using either an internal viewer or a PDF viewer extension); otherwise false.

NavigatorPermissions.summary:
The permissions read-only property of the interface returns a
object that can be used to query and update permission
status of APIs covered by the Permissions API.

remarks.para:
-Permissions API
-

NavigatorPlatform.summary: The platform property read-only property of the interface returns a string identifying the platform on which the user's browser is running.

blockquote.para: In general, you should whenever possible avoid writing code that uses methods or properties like this one to try to find out information about the user's environment, and instead write code that does feature detection.

remarks.para: -navigator.userAgentData.platform

NavigatorPlatform.value: A string identifying the platform on which the user's browser is running; for example: "MacIntel", "Win32", "Linux x86_64", "Linux armv81".

NavigatorPlugins.summary:
Returns a object, listing the objects describing the plugins installed in the application.
Named properties of the returned object are not enumerable (except in very old browser versions).

remarks.para:
Recent versions of the specification hard-code the returned list.
If inline viewing of PDF files is supported the property lists five standard plugins.
If inline PDF viewing is not supported then an empty list is returned.

blockquote.para: Use to determine if inline viewing of PDF files is supported. Do not infer it from this property.

The "five standard plugins" are those that developers have most commonly used to feature detect inline PDF viewing.
Returning these ensures that legacy code can more reliably determine whether inline viewing is supported.
However this approach is not recommended for new code because this property may eventually be removed.

remarks.para: Legacy browser versions also list plugins for Adobe Flash and PDF viewer extensions.

NavigatorPlugins.value: plugins is a object used to access objects either by name or as a list of items.The returned value is not a JavaScript array, but has the length property and supports accessing individual items using bracket notation (plugins[2]), as well as via item(index) and namedItem("name") methods.If PDF inline viewing is supported this will contain entries for the following plugins:If inline viewing of PDFs is not supported then an empty object is returned.

NavigatorPresentation.summary:
The presentation read-only property of serves as the entry
point for the Presentation API and
returns a reference to object.

remarks.para:
-Presentation API
-

NavigatorProduct.summary:
The value of the Navigator.product property is always
"Gecko", in any browser. This property is kept only for compatibility
purposes.

blockquote.para: Do not rely on this property to return a real product name. All browsers return "Gecko" as the value of this property.

NavigatorProductSub.summary: The Navigator.productSub read-only property that returns either the string "20030107", or the string "20100101".

NavigatorRegisterProtocolHandler.summary: The method registerProtocolHandler() lets websites register their ability to open or handle particular URL schemes (also known as protocols).

remarks.para: For example, this API lets webmail sites open mailto: URLs, or VoIP sites open tel: URLs.
To register a protocol handler, a website calls registerProtocolHandler(), passing in the protocol to register and a template URL.

When the user activates a link that uses the registered protocol, the browser will insert the href from the activated link into the URL template supplied during handler registration, and navigate the current page to the resulting URL.
The browser may ask the user to confirm that they want the page to be allowed to handle the protocol, either when the protocol is registered or when the user activates the link.

NavigatorRequestMediaKeySystemAccess.summary: The requestMediaKeySystemAccess() method of the interface returns a {{jsxref('Promise')}} which delivers a object that can be used to access a particular media key system, which can in turn be used to create keys for decrypting a media stream.

remarks.para: This method is part of the Encrypted Media Extensions API, which brings support for encrypted media and DRM-protected video to the web.

This method may have user-visible effects such as asking for permission to access one or more system resources.
Consider that when deciding when to call requestMediaKeySystemAccess(); you don't want those requests to happen at inconvenient times.
As a general rule, this function should be called only when it's about time to create and use a object by calling the returned object's method.

-Encrypted Media Extensions API
-Media Capture and Streams API
-WebRTC API
-

NavigatorRequestMediaKeySystemAccess.returns: A {{jsxref('Promise')}} that fulfils with a object representing the media key system configuration described by keySystem and supportedConfigurations.

NavigatorRequestMIDIAccess.summary:
The requestMIDIAccess() method of the interface returns a {{jsxref('Promise')}} representing a request for access to MIDI devices on a user's system.
This method is part of the Web MIDI API, which provides a means for accessing, enumerating, and manipulating MIDI devices.

remarks.para:
This method may prompt the user for access to MIDI devices available to their system, or it may use a previously established preference to grant or deny access.
If permission is granted then the resolves and a MIDIAccess object is returned.

-Web MIDI API
-Introduction to Web MIDI

NavigatorRequestMIDIAccess.returns: A that resolves with a MIDIAccess object.

NavigatorScheduling.summary: NOTE Experimental The scheduling read-only property of the interface returns a object for the current document, which provides methods and properties to control scheduling tasks.

blockquote.para: The interface (which includes the method) has been superseded by the interface, the features of which are better designed for addressing scheduling tasks. See Don't use isInputPending() for more details.

remarks.para:
- interface
-{{domxref("Prioritized_task_scheduling_api", "Prioritized Task Scheduling API", "", "nocode")}}
-Faster input events with Facebook's first browser API contribution on engineering.fb.com (2019)
-Better JS scheduling with isInputPending() on developer.chrome.com (2020)
-Optimizing long tasks on web.dev (2022)

NavigatorSendBeacon.summary:
The navigator.sendBeacon()
method Asynchronous sends an HTTP POST request containing a small amount of data to a web server.

remarks.para:
It's intended to be used for
sending analytics data to a web server, and avoids some of the problems with
legacy techniques for sending analytics, such as the use of
.

blockquote.para: For use cases that need the ability to send requests with methods other than POST, or to change any request properties, or that need access to the server response, instead use the fetch() method with keepalive set to true.

remarks.para:
-The visibilitychange event.
-{{domxref("Beacon_API","Beacon API", "", "true")}} overview page.
-Don't lose user and app state, use Page Visibility explains in
detail why you should use visibilitychange, not
beforeunload/unload.
-Page Lifecycle API gives best-practices guidance on handling
page lifecycle behavior in your web applications.
-PageLifecycle.js: a JavaScript library that deals with cross-browser inconsistencies in page lifecycle behavior.
-Back/forward cache explains what the back/forward cache is, and its implications for various page lifecycle events.

NavigatorSendBeacon.returns:
The sendBeacon() method returns true if the
user agent successfully queued the data for transfer.
Otherwise, it returns false.

NavigatorSerial.summary: NOTE Experimental The serial read-only property of the interface returns a object which represents the entry point into the Web Serial API.

remarks.para: When getting, the same instance of the object will always be returned.

-Read from and write to a serial port
-Getting started with the web serial API

NavigatorServiceWorker.summary: The serviceWorker read-only property of the interface returns the object for the associated document, which provides access to registration, removal, upgrade, and communication with the .

remarks.para: The feature may not be available in private mode.
Note that a worker can similarly access the for a document using .

-{{domxref("Service Worker API", "", "", "nocode")}}
-Using Service Workers

NavigatorSetAppBadge.summary: The setAppBadge() method of the interface sets a badge on the icon associated with this app. If a value is passed to the method, this will be set as the value of the badge. Otherwise the badge will display as a dot, or other indicator as defined by the platform.

remarks.para: -Badging for app icons

NavigatorShare.summary: The share() method of the interface invokes the native sharing mechanism of the device to share data such as text, URLs, or files. The available share targets depend on the device, but might include the clipboard, contacts and email applications, websites, Bluetooth, etc.

remarks.para:
The method resolves a with undefined.
On Windows this happens when the share popup is launched, while on Android the promise resolves once the data has successfully been passed to the share target.

The Web Share API is gated by the web-share permission policy.
The share() method will throw exceptions if the permission is supported but has not been granted.

-
- (web platform tests)

NavigatorShare.returns: A that resolves with undefined, or rejected with one of the Exceptions given below.

NavigatorStorage.summary:
The Navigator.storage
read-only property returns the singleton object used to
access the overall storage capabilities of the browser for the current site or app.
The returned object lets you examine and configure persistence of data stores and
learn approximately how much more space your browser has available for local storage
use.
NavigatorStorage.value:
A object you can use to maintain persistence for stored
data, as well as to determine roughly how much room there is for data to be stored.

NavigatorTaintEnabled.summary:
The Navigator.taintEnabled() method always returns
false.

remarks.para:
Tainting was a security method used by JavaScript 1.2. It has long been removed; this
method only stays for maintaining compatibility with very old scripts.

NavigatorUnregisterProtocolHandler.summary: The method unregisterProtocolHandler() removes a protocol handler for a given URL scheme.

remarks.para: This method is the inverse of registerProtocolHandler().

NavigatorUsb.summary: The usb read-only property of the interface returns a object for the current document, providing access to WebUSB API functionality.

remarks.para: -WebUSB API

NavigatorUserActivation.summary: The read-only userActivation property of the interface returns a object which contains information about the current window's user activation state.

remarks.para:
-
-
-
-Features gated by user activation

NavigatorUserAgent.summary:
The Navigator.userAgent read-only property returns the
user agent string for the current browser.

blockquote.para:
The specification asks browsers to provide as little information via this field as
possible. Never assume that the value of this property will stay the same in future
versions of the same browser. Try not to use it at all, or only for current and past
versions of a browser. New browsers may start using the same UA, or part of it, as an
older browser: you really have no guarantee that the browser agent is indeed the one
advertised by this property.

Also keep in mind that users of a browser can change the value of this field if they
want (UA spoofing).

remarks.para:
Browser identification based on detecting the user agent string is
unreliable and is not recommended, as the user agent
string is user configurable. For example:
-User-Agent HTTP header

NavigatorUserAgent.value:
A string specifying the complete user agent string the browser
provides both in HTTP headers and in response to this and other related
methods on the object.The user agent string is built on a formal structure which can be decomposed into
several pieces of info. Each of these pieces of info comes from other navigator
properties which are also settable by the user. For more information about the
form of the user agent string, see the User-agent HTTP header.

NavigatorUserAgentData.summary:
NOTE Experimental The userAgentData read-only property of the interface returns a object
which can be used to access the {{domxref("User-Agent Client Hints API", "", "", "nocode")}}.

remarks.para:
-HTTP Client hints
-Improving user privacy and developer experience with User-Agent Client Hints

NavigatorVendor.summary: The value of the vendor property is always either "Google Inc.", "Apple Computer, Inc.", or (in Firefox) the empty string.
NavigatorVendor.value: Either "Google Inc.", "Apple Computer, Inc.", or (in Firefox) the empty string.

NavigatorVendorSub.summary:
The value of the Navigator.vendorSub property is always
the empty string, in any browser.

NavigatorVibrate.summary:
The vibrate() method of the interface pulses the vibration
hardware on the device, if such hardware exists. If the device doesn't support
vibration, this method has no effect. If a vibration pattern is already in progress when
this method is called, the previous pattern is halted and the new one begins instead.

remarks.para:
If the method was unable to vibrate because of invalid parameters, it will return
false, else it returns true. If the pattern leads to a too
long vibration, it is truncated: the max length depends on the implementation.

Some devices may not vibrate if they are in Silent mode or Do Not Disturb (DND) mode. To ensure vibration works, make sure these modes are turned off and that vibration is enabled in the system settings.
-Vibration API

NavigatorVirtualKeyboard.summary:
NOTE Experimental The virtualKeyboard read-only property
of the interface returns a reference to the instance object.

remarks.para: The {{domxref("VirtualKeyboard_API", "VirtualKeyboard API", "", "nocode")}} gives developers control over the layout of their applications when the on-screen virtual keyboard appears and disappears on devices such as tablets, mobile phones, or other devices where a hardware keyboard may not be available.

NavigatorVirtualKeyboard.value: A object you can use to opt-out of the automatic virtual keyboard behavior, show or hide the virtual keyboard programmatically, and get the current position and size of the virtual keyboard.

NavigatorWakeLock.summary:
The wakeLock read-only property of the interface returns a interface that allows a document to acquire a screen wake lock.
While a screen wake lock is active, the user agent will try to prevent the device from dimming the screen, turning it off completely, or showing a screensaver.

remarks.para:
-
-Screen Wake Lock API
-Stay awake with the Screen Wake Lock API

NavigatorWebdriver.summary:
The webdriver read-only property
of the interface indicates whether the user agent is
controlled by automation.

remarks.para:
It defines a standard way for co-operating user agents to inform the document that it
is controlled by WebDriver, for example, so that
alternate code paths can be triggered during automation.
The navigator.webdriver property is true when in:

NavigatorWindowControlsOverlay.summary:
The windowControlsOverlay read-only property of the
interface returns the interface, which exposes
information about the title bar geometry in desktop Progressive Web Apps that use the Window Controls Overlay API.

remarks.para:
Progressive Web Apps installed on desktop Operating Systems can opt-in to the
Window Controls Overlay feature by using the window-controls-overlay value in the
display_override web app manifest member.

Doing so hides the default window title bar and gives the app access to the full area
of the app window.

NavigatorXr.summary:
NOTE Experimental The read-only xr property
provided by the interface returns an object
which can be used to access the WebXR Device API.

remarks.para:
-WebGL API: 2D and 3D accelerated
graphics for the web
-Canvas API: 2D graphics API

NavigatorXr.value:
The object used to interface with the WebXR Device API in the current
context. This can be used to present augmented and/or virtual reality imagery to the
user.
